segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Mrs. Barbara Mikowychok-chuk(ph) Syska. Ill repeat that. Mrs. Barbara Mikowychuk(ph) Syska, on October 22™, 2014, here at the Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C. And I’d like to start out by thanking you very much to come to speak with us today. I appreciate the time that you’re going to take, and the experiences that you’re going to share. As I explained a little earlier, we start our interviews from the very beginning. We’d like to learn a little bit about your pre- war life, your family, the world you were born into, and so on. So I’II start with the very basic questions. Could you tell me the date you were born, your name at birth, and where you were born?
segments.answer: I was born in Bialystok, 20 — May 24, ’27. My name is Barbara Joanna(ph) sys — sorry, Mikowychuk(ph) Syska, by my husband.

segments.question: So that means your maiden name was Mikowychuk(ph)?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. And you were born in Bialystok?
segments.answer: Yes, in the city — in the hospital there.

segments.question: Ah. Can you tell us — because some people will know what that is and where that is, others will not know. Can you tell us a little bit about the city? Interview with Barbara Syska , October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Bialystok was the center city for the county of Bialostocka(ph) Voivoidsfa(ph). Voivoidsfa(ph) Bialostotsky(ph), that’s come from Bialystok. There was one hospital at that time. I lived, for the first year, somewhere on the ci — in the city. And when I was a year, or a year and a half, we moved to the part close to Palac Branitsky, is Palace of Branitsky.

segments.question: And where’s that?
segments.answer: I-In there, on part, they were divided, so there was a fence between the one park and the other. One was the school, which was just ordinary school with the school for the teachers. The other was the ci-city of Bialystok where — where magistrat(ph) is.

segments.question: Was municipal authorities?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And at that part there was also a big lake where we used to slide during the night — du-during the winter.

segments.question: So it would be frozen over?
segments.answer: Why we moved to that part, which was the school, because my mother was a teacher. Both of my parents has only education up to the matriculation.

segments.question: What does that mean, matriculation? High school, or some college? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska ° October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Twelve. High school, high school.

segments.question: High school. Gymnasium, and so, yeah.
segments.answer: They didn’t have anything farther than that. So my mother was specialized in teaching the teachers, and because of that, she was teaching e-even in high school, the 10" and 11" — well, 13 grade. At that time the teacher, after 12 of the 13 grade. Otherwise, she has only the right to teach up to the ninth — sixth grade, sorry. The school was divided six grades, four grades and two top, and then you have the high school.

segments.question: So your mother was a teacher. Was your father also a teacher?
segments.answer: No. He was the — they met in Wejherowa, it’s close to the sea. She was a teacher and he wanted to be the soldier. And she convinced him to leave the army. I have no idea what happened during the war on 20 for my father.

segments.question: In 1920.
segments.answer: Because he — in 1920, he was 22. So most likely he was in the army. They never talk about that. The only thing my mother convince him to leave the army. And because he was in the army before, he was the army reserve. So from time to time he had to go and learn a bit more for a week or two. Otherwise, he was a clerk. A — most likely he was an accountant. I didn’t know much about tt.

segments.question: I see. Interview with Barbara Syska ° October 22, 2014
segments.answer: And we lived in the buildings close to the palace.

segments.question: What’s a powets? What’s a powets?
segments.answer: Palace.

segments.question: Palace, okay.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. The buildings were built — when I visit after the war, the walls were most likely close to a meter wide. So it was always warm, but of course for the restroom we would have to go — share it with two other families and go downstairs somewhere. There was no hot water, and things like that, because the building at that time was already 150 years old.

segments.question: How was it that you lived in this palace?
segments.answer: Because my mother was teaching in the school. So we —

segments.question: And the school was located in the palace?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: I see. Okay.
segments.answer: Oh, part of it.

segments.question: I see. I see.
segments.answer: And in the — there was a beautiful park, there were tennis courts, which are very, very expensive, but I was not athletic. My brother, four years older than I am, was in tennis and swimming and everything. In Bialystok there wasn’t — there was a Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska ' October 22, 2014 river, but the river whose — which smells very, very badly, because Bialystok is a town of industry for clothing.

segments.question: Textiles.
segments.answer: And every — textile. And everything went into that river, and vo — very small river. It used to be called Biatka(ph). Right now they call it Bialy Rzeka — Rzeka Bialy, which means White River. It was really nothing, it was smelly always, not transparent, but no — nor — no animals, no nothing.

segments.question: So it’s polluted.
segments.answer: Enormously polluted. You can’t imagine.

segments.question: Even before the war?
segments.answer: Before the war. They were going to put it into underground. What they did afterwards, I don’t know. I visited Bialystok only once from this country, and it was completely different. Before the war, it was 104,000 people. And apparently half of the population was Jewish. I thought it only about a third. Part of the poorest part was Jewish, and they were all — also little shacks where they were selling every — food and everything, so we would go there. And I’m sure that 1t was completely burned while eur — when the Jewish people were fighting.

segments.answer: But I wasn’t there at that time. Why I say about my father and about the — his experience, because when the war started, he had to go to the army, and with his army, he was going back, back, back —

And I have a few questions already from what you were telling me, and they’re factual kinds of questions.
segments.answer: One thing also.

segments.question: Sure.
segments.answer: My mother had a servant —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — who was taking care of me, and cooking, because she was a teacher. But she was paying a lot. It we — the servant lived with us, and she was paying 25 zloty. If you could somehow — I think that her monthly was 200, or something like that, her moth — my mother’s. So —

segments.question: Your monthly — your mother’s monthly salary was 200 zloty?
segments.answer: I think so, but I am not sure. I know that she was paying not 20, but 25 zloty to the servant. Interview with Barbara Syska ” October 22, 2014

segments.question: Per week or per month?
segments.answer: For a month. For a month.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And most of the servants had very little education. For one, her daughter was somewhere, and I was writing the letter, which she was — so, she was completely — couldn’t say anything.

segments.question: So she was not literate.
segments.answer: Not — not at all.

segments.question: So you would write letters for her to her daughter?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And so, that I know. We lived in a convertible place. My father, my mother, my brother, four years older, I and the servant.

segments.answer: He was born in ’23.

segments.answer: Antonyen(ph).

segments.answer: Antony(ph).

segments.answer: No, no, no.

segments.answer: My father was from Warsaw, and my mother from Przemysl. Well, Warsaw is west of Bialystok, and PrzemySl is south. And I can tell you this story of my family.

segments.answer: Young boy. And he saw that Turk coming, and he killed him. segments.answer: But I really respect her, that being from poor to — and this is most likely completely true story.

segments.question: Well, you know what 1s also interesting is that it is a story that was passed down through those 11 generations, to you. That is, it’s something that stayed within the family —
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.answer: Well, in Poland there is a custom that if a father had three sons or 10 sons, his property is divided equally, except if somebody goes to priesthood.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So they were pushing boys to priesthood so they would — and because of that, the noble people were sometimes have the piece of land just as m-much as the peasant. And the story, but I don’t know, it was mo — most likely my grandfather — Poland was taken by Russia and — and so on, three times. And once, my grandfather as a baby, was carried through the border in a wash basket. So —

segments.question: From Russia into —
segments.answer: — then they didn’t have — from Humanya(ph), which was Poland —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — and right now is Ukraine, middle of Ukraine somewhere.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: I always hoped to — to go there and see whether there are any Czynski(ph) there.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But most likely not. I don’t know. But anyway, so they moved, and my mother was in Przemysl, somewhere connected with [indecipherable]. My grandfather died when she was one year old.

Well, three is easier than four. She managed somehow.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: She gave good education for —

segments.question: All her daughters.
segments.answer: Good —

segments.question: Yeah, all her children.
segments.answer: Yes, yes. And she was working with a nurse na — nurse, servant and nurse. They were cooking and giving lunches to people who were coming, that’s how she supported herself and four children.

segments.question: So that’s your grandmother.
segments.answer: That’s my grandmother.

segments.question: What — what a story.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: What a story. Interview with Barbara Syska : October 22, 2014
segments.answer: So, we believe that wom — women are equal, but completely different. But we are equal.

segments.question: Yeah. Well, you survived, and —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — and she brought up her children.
segments.answer: Yes. So she was a teacher, and because of that we lived there. And she had a servant, she had to, but in comparison I can’t — did — I didn’t say how big was our —

segments.question: Yeah, tell me.
segments.answer: — apartment. Four of us and the servant, there were two rooms. One little room connected with two rooms, and kitchen, and so they couldn’t be — that room could not be used for anything, only just storage of — cupboard. And the servant sleeps in the kitchen.

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: When the Soviets expelled us, a man came in and my mother says, well, we’re here only, and [indecipherable] there no room. And he said, oh, in our country even Stalin doesn’t have such a good room. And he believed.

segments.question: Yeah, he believed, yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: He believed. But it was really very small, but that was cheaper than — because of Interview with Barbara Syska .° October 22, 2014

segments.question: She taught —
segments.answer: — it was only for teachers —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — so it was slightly cheaper, I don’t know how much it was.

segments.question: So, I got the impression — tell us again, there will be people who know geographically where Bialystok is, and others who don’t. Can you tell us where in Poland the city is?
segments.answer: It’s halfway from Warszawa to — you say Vilnius, I’m saying Wilno.

segments.question: So it’s halfway between Warsaw and Wilno, and Wilno is in Lithuania, so that means it’s in eastern Poland.
segments.answer: Yes, right now it’s very easter, but is part of — biggest part of Poland was taken by Soviet Union.

segments.question: So that means that it’s in the northeastern part, so —
segments.answer: Slightly north to the Warsaw, but it’s not very far. I think, if I’m right, it’s 110 kilometers. That means about 18 miles from Warsaw. And when my brother finished his middle school gymnasium, four years, that’s the 10" grade, he decided to go and visit my aunt, which was in Pruszkow, which is very close to wa — Warsaw, and my grandparents were in Warsaw — on the bicycle. And he made it in Interview with Barbara Syska v October 22, 2014 one day, but the more — most thing difficult was the first part, because it was not paved. It was just a road. And that’s the main road from Warsaw to Wilno.

segments.question: Now, within Bialystok, were the roads paved?
segments.answer: They were something what we call koci bur(ph), cat’s heads. It’s a —

segments.question: Cobblestones.
segments.answer: Cobblestone.

segments.question: Cobblestones, I see.
segments.answer: Mostly, and there will — will be some which wer — weren’t paved at all.

segments.answer: A — one of the teachers, they didn’t have children, have a car. And we used to come and see how he was working with the car. You have the handle in front —

segments.question: Oh yeah.
segments.answer: — and move it.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And that’s how you start the —

segments.answer: Yes, that kind. So I saw the car, and I saw the first plane, it was the first few days of the war. I was coming — I’m somewhere close to that bielka(ph) and the plane flew over it, very close. That was the closest to the planes.

segments.question: So that’s the first time you saw an airplane —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — was when the war starts.
segments.answer: Yes, when the war st —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: My daughter had the plane to — she used to [indecipherable] the plane. She still have it, I think it doesn’t play. And my youngest son is a pilot since he was 17. He is in Poland right now. But I saw the first plane.

segments.answer: Well, he’s ple — flying helicopters, but —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So the war — the world change very much. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014

segments.question: Yes it has, hasn’t it? It really has. In — in Bialystok, what would — was it a pretty city, or was it a very, as you Say, if it was industrial —
segments.answer: I don’t know where industry was. I was close to — well, from us it was very close to — to the main market there. And I would go with the servant to — when she was shopping in Hahnyehki(ph). Does — that Jewish part.

segments.question: Hahnyehki(ph)?
segments.answer: Hahnyehki(ph).

segments.question: Okay. Did you have any Jewish friends?
segments.answer: Yes. There were — there were two kids in my class.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And one was a boy, and one a girl. The girl, nothing special. The boy was the most intelligent and he usually didn’t get the best grades, and I did.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: And I was completely sure that he was much brighter than I was. So — but the teacher was giving the boy less than me.

segments.question: Why would — why would that be?
segments.answer: She was divorced and my mother said that she didn’t like the boys. But an- anyway, she recognize him and very often when the war in Spain started —

segments.answer: — she usually would say [indecipherable] say wha-what’s happening in — in — and he was saying. He was completely sure. He was in second grade or something, and knew what was happening in Spain.

segments.question: The Spanish Civil War.
segments.answer: The Spanish Civil War.

segments.question: Civil War, in ’37.
segments.answer: He was really a bright boy. Now, there was one child who was a — e-easter Orthodox. The — so three out of about 40. Our classes were large because it was — the school was called Treitanufka(ph), something what you learn how to do it. So they —

segments.question: Vocational school.
segments.answer: Vo — it was vocation for the teacher. The mother — my mother was teaching the grades. And the [indecipherable] pedagogic.

segments.answer: Yes, and those teachers had to learn on us. And since in the country there were big classes — usually, I think, in Poland were, in cities it will be 30 in class. But in ours 1t was 40, and once I was 1n a connected school, connected class, third and fourth grade together, 60 kids all together, so the teacher would learn how to do it. Only one year like that. So, there were big classes. That was not discrimination, they a -— all — all the children were very, very glad to leave and do whatever they want.

segments.question: Not have to be — yeah.
segments.answer: No, that was definitely not discrimination, they could stay and learn. Our — for instance, we start with the prayer. They would not have to pray with us, only they have to stand up on the very beginning and the very end of the school. But they would have to pass religion to pass to the next grade. So —

segments.question: Their own religion?
segments.answer: Their own religion. So the rabbi has to say that they passed the religion for the, say second grade, before they will go to the third. But what they learn, that was his only. He did not have to say what he consider good for the second grade.

segments.question: And you’re saying this was true for the Orthodox children as well?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay. And were there many Orthodox children?
segments.answer: In my class, only one.

segments.answer: Mm-hm, mm-hm.

segments.answer: Kind of Polish.

segments.answer: They knew that the — the others are strangers, the others are occupa — occupants.

segments.answer: That was during the war. And he lived with us, he came to United States, he lived with us for a week or two. And right now, if he’s alive, he’s still teaching in an — Ann Arbor. But that came, that one year everything was — was bad, it was supposed to be bad because of Jewish people. And I think something was bad, people can’t take very easily. So most likely right now there is the real anti- Semitism in part of Poland, not to everybody.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But it was definitely — I — I want to give you what was before the war. There were some —

Last few years we e — if we could avoid. And the reason was economic, because before Poland received independence into ninet — 18 — Jewish people were taking part of commerce. It was an old cemetery where they were mem — monument for — to remember French people who died in the first World War, and they put the plaque there, and they invited everybody, but only I and one of my son came, because they couldn’t find any others.

segments.question: Any other people from the other famil — from the others who died?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Let’s go back now to what happened with yourself, your mother and your father.
