Your mother is teaching in — what was the town’s name, Pruszkow? Pr — Interview with Barbara Syska . October 22, 2014
segments.answer: N-No, no, no, Pruszkow is where my aunt was, and where I lived. She was in Kozietuly, beyond Gruyetz(ph), which is south of France, in a big village. There were two — 2,000 people living there, it’s one of the biggest villages.

segments.question: South of Warsaw?
segments.answer: South of Warsaw.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And so when the Germans attacked Russians, forget that they friends.

segments.question: That was a —
segments.answer: They forget —

segments.question: That was June 21*, yes.
segments.answer: Then she took me back, and I was learning from the books on there. A-And that taught me a lot. Something was usually — people, when they’re at universities, learn how to study. I learned there. I lar — lar — learned to like learning.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Under such circumstances — explain for us, explain to people why were these schools illegal?
segments.answer: Because ev — Germans said everything illegal after the sixth grade. Why? The low people like Polish people shouldn’t learn any more. So after I came again to Interview with Barbara Syska mc October 22, 2014 Warsaw, when my father brought me, it was the trade school. Of course, it was still illegal, we had books at home. And when we came to — there was advertising was one class. So we were talking, not looking at the teacher as well, because something for — for the schoolwork. But, for instance, mathematics. We had books at home. We had do this and that and that on the page.

segments.question: So you had homework.
segments.answer: And then we would come — yes, under German occ-occupation then. And the teacher would ask who had trouble with school. And somebody would say, I cannot do the third one. So come to the blackboard and we’ ll explain. That was the kind of le — teaching usually when you’re in school you do not say that you cannot do something. There it was the opposite. And at that school — I should really come late — when I was in — in the country with my mother, my only problem, she didn’t know Latin, and in Polish school you have to have Latin. So I had trouble with Latin later on when I was in proper school. But it was cold, 1t was a very old building, and it was wet. So my mother — it was on the second floor, we lived on second — that was where the teacher lived. And on the first floor my — my mother would go and teach kids, and I was in bed with my coat, and on the walls during the winter, there was frost.

segments.question: So you — on the inside of the walls of the building — Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014
segments.answer: It was still —

segments.question: — it was frosty.
segments.answer: Yes, we had only one out of — we had four rooms, I think, or two rooms. There was one stove, but we didn’t had —

segments.question: Have heat.
segments.answer: [indecipherable]. And there was a small rail close by. So I— my mother and would go and that train was using coal, so from time to time something would fall, so we were looking for granules of coal. And yes, it was cold. But my father said no, you — you cannot be there, you have to go to school. How he found the school, through whom that they would trust me that they would be there, because of course, everybody could always say something. So my moth — my father —

segments.question: I’m sorry, I need to interrupt a little bit, just to clarify. Your mother is in this village outside of Warsaw and she’s teaching legally, because the children are younger than sixth grade.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: So she’s earning a salary by doing it, and doesn’t have to worry about this.
segments.answer: Except that the salary was roughly the same salary as before the war, and the prices went up.

segments.question: Of course. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska . October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Luckily, custom 1n the village is to bring two eggs, to bring an apple, to bring something. And we had a little plot of land where we could grow something.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Not too much, but something, as well.

segments.question: So when your father comes back from having been released from prison —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — in about the summer of 1941, does he find you and your mother in this village?
segments.answer: Yes, because he had sister in pr — Pruszkéw, which is close to Warsaw, and his parents in Warsaw itself.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: Sorry, not parents, my grandfather died in ’39, where Germans was fighting about Warsaw. And my grandmother was very, very frightened of everything, and everybody thought that if you go to the cellar it will be safer, and everybody was going to the cellar, and somebody pushed my grandfather — by — by chance. He fell, and was unconscious til — til the very end of the — of his life. And that was soon after Germans took Warsaw. But my mo — my grandmother was very, very frightened, so she took him to — to his bedroom, second or third floor, I don’t remember, instead of going to the cellar where —

segments.question: Everybody else was, yeah. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014
segments.answer: And she put, not to hear so much noise, she put her — what’s — what do you call? Something what you cover yourself in bed?

segments.question: Blankets, duvets?
segments.answer: Not blanket, but something fluffy.

segments.question: Something fluffy? A quilt?
segments.answer: Yes. She put the quilt into the —

segments.question: Windows?
segments.answer: — windows, so that she wouldn’t hear so much, and stayed with him all that time.

segments.question: Oh my. And yet she —
segments.answer: She died soon after.

segments.question: Did she, yeah. And so your father, when he came back, he found you with your mother together —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — in this one — and how — did he move in with you, or did he move you to Warsaw? What happened?
segments.answer: No, he went to Warsaw by himself, and joined the [indecipherable] army [speaks Polish]. That was before Armia Kryova. Armia Kryova is home army. [speaks Polish] — when I joined, it was Armia Kryova. And after a time, it was beginning of 1943, he took me to Warsaw. And on the very beginning I had to have Interview with Barbara Syska i October 22, 2014 some papers, safe papers, because without the papers anybody could be sent to Germany straight away. So I was working to Red Cross. I was in archives, so I learned how to put it. Everything was what finished, I was supposed to put in the sides.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I didn’t know at that time, but the daughter of my boss, she was in Armia Kryova, so maybe that’s where I — my father found the work for me. And another thing he said, that time there came a — through Red Cross, a letter, which I remember by heart. I’m okay. I only lack news about you. In Polish it was. And so I hope that — that came before that, about two or three months earlier. So —

segments.question: Who was it from?
segments.answer: From my brother. Through Red Cross you can get the message like that, it’s open message. And it came to my aunt, because he knew — he didn’t know that we were in Warsaw at that time. He didn’t know anything about us. We didn’t know — but th — for the first time we learned that he 1s alive. I always believed, but my parents thought that he didn’t — that he died.

segments.question: They didn’t know that he had been arrested. They didn’t know that he — Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014
segments.answer: He learn — my father learn about him being arrested when he was in prison. Somebody apparently was transferred from one prison to another. So my father learned there. Because we thought the he went to France and maybe he died there —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: — fighting with the Polish army.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But instead my father learn, and because of that, after he was released finally from —

segments.question: Siberia.
segments.answer: — prison, he went and waited in Bialystok —

segments.question: Your father.
segments.answer: — because he thought that maybe my brother will also come. But my brother was arrested half a year earlier. Almost half a year. So, he was already sent out to prison.

segments.question: So your mother, did she stay the entire war in this village, teaching in that school?
segments.answer: Up to the first days of insurrection in Warsaw.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: In my — bef — well, first of all, my father — I thought that — about the father, you always think that he’s old. In ’43, he was 45. Interview with Barbara Syska ia October 22, 2014

segments.question: Oh, that’s young.
segments.answer: And he didn’t know what his only son did, but he took his daughter, me, into the army. So I joined the a — joined the army, I — my solemn swearing was on the fifth of August, but much before that, I was already the messenger.

segments.question: So you were in Armia Kryova.
segments.answer: Armia Kryova.

segments.question: And your s — and your swearing in was fifth of August, 1943?
segments.answer: Yes, but I was much before that —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — because during the summer I was working in those ar — archives, and I was definitely at that time already in the Armia Kryova.

segments.question: So that meant you were 15 years old, 16 years old, something —
segments.answer: Sixteen.

segments.question: Sixteen.
segments.answer: Sixteen.

segments.question: Sixteen.
segments.answer: And so what I was doing, I don’t remember. First of all, my father was at the command of the [Polish]. Middle force, 1t was divided into, I think four pieces. And he was in the second on in the comman — command of the second one. Interview with Barbara Syska ~ October 22, 2014

segments.question: Uh-huh. The second sort of area.
segments.answer: And he was not the commander, he was in the command. He — one of his things wa — jobs was taking care of the five messengers.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: In between I was.

segments.question: And you were one of the five?
segments.answer: Wa- one of the five. And the whole structure, wherever it was possible, was the fifth, because you expect that if somebody will be arrested a day or two, he may su- survive the tre —

segments.question: Torture?
segments.answer: Torture. But you cannot count for always. And because of that, if it’s only five people who know each other, then you can told this for disappear, because somebody is already there. And that way it was safer.

segments.question: So, did any of the five that you were part of a group, did any of them get arrested by the Germans?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But one died, I have to tell you, because well —

segments.question: Please do. Interview with Barbara Syska ™ October 22, 2014
segments.answer: — if — instead of me. But anyway, just before the commander of that second [indecipherable], was — had tuberculosis. In a very bad shape, and he had to be in hospital. And of course, if somebody will say anything, so in hospital you cannot run away from it. So, he didn’t have children — he survived the insurrection. Only his wife, his second-in-command and I knew where he was. So if something were — messages to him were going through me. Because if, for instance, my father did not know in hos — which hospital, nothing. So he was safe. He went out of the hospital, I think about a month before insurrection. And my biggest experience during the insurrection was, I was just trying to find out what — we know the date, but what day of the week it was. It was — insurrection started Tuesday. And we have in the yard of the house where was the command, we have the mass for soldiers. So 1t was not the first day. Is on a Sunday then. And after that he came to me and ask me, how do you feel in free Poland? And I looked at them, I remember that I did not know what to say, and I don’t remember wha — after that I say. But finally I realize, this little piece of land 1s free Poland. And for me the whole insurrection was because of that, I was in free Poland. People were dying around me, I could die as well, but the — the important thing is, we are already in free Poland. That little piece is ours. And that changed my whole look at the — peoples say trad — tragedy, or something Interview with Barbara Syska a October 22, 2014 like that. To me it was something, fight in free Poland. And that’s what — what he said.

segments.question: Who was this person who said that?
segments.answer: He — he was the commander of the second —

segments.question: Ah, the one who had been in the hospital?
segments.answer: Yes, that’s one.

segments.question: And so his —
segments.answer: And under him there were 2,000 people prepared. I learn later, from another — in his command there were a man who was taking care of something, as — I don’t — don’t know what’s the in command, in — in — in military, I don’t know. But he told me that there were two — 2,000 people in that place.

segments.question: Do you remember his name, the commander?
segments.answer: His sa — surname was Litvin(ph). Oh, Ill tell you later.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I—I know his name. And it happened that after the war he was in Gdansk and my — one of my aunts was there, and they met. So [indecipherable] Abramovicz(ph).

segments.question: Abramovicz(ph).
segments.answer: Abramovicz was first name — don’t remember. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska "° October 22, 2014

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Litvin(ph).

segments.question: So his last name was Abramovicz(ph)? His surname was Abramovicz(ph)?
segments.answer: Abramovicz(ph) and Litvin(ph) is his —

segments.question: A pseudonym.
segments.answer: — pseudonym.

segments.question: Yeah. Actually, it sounds like a Jewish name.
segments.answer: I don’t think he was Jewish, no.

segments.question: No? I heard that quite a few people were a part of the insurrection, the Warsaw uprising, who were of Jewish background.
segments.answer: Definitely yes. And I’Il have to tell you all about my little hero.

segments.question: Okay, tell —
segments.answer: Anyway —

segments.question: Tell me.
segments.answer: —I lived through the insurrection in that part of Poland, in Warsaw.

segments.question: Warsaw.
segments.answer: We - we never had to go through the nin — sewers.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014
segments.answer: So it was the safest. But anyway, one day somebody was silly enough to say that all people who went from old city, where the fighting was the worst, should sign that they — they knew. And they were gathering around the church.

segments.question: They should sign something?
segments.answer: Yes. They should be who survived and so on.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And Germans were flying over that, and people were coming to that. And we were supposed to work there, our five. And the top of our five was a chemist, and she came after her shift, she came for me, and I was asleep. And she said, well, she’s so fast asleep, P’ll go back. And she died there.

segments.question: She was bombed?
segments.answer: They were bombed. Of course, when everybody is gathering, it’s worthwhile. [indecipherable]

segments.question: So do you think was done on purpose?
segments.answer: German did it on purpose.

segments.question: Yeah, yeah, but the — the —
segments.answer: No, no, that was a silly comment.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: People are always silly. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska ™ October 22, 2014

segments.question: Unfortunately.
segments.answer: Once I remember I was going somewhere. There was a lot of blood on — and that was terrible, I never seen. There was somebody — we had [indecipherable] something we — when you, every day you say — say apple, and you have to answer pear —

segments.question: Oh, you had a password.
segments.answer: Passwords.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And somebody who came from old city, where the fighting was the worst, when they came through the sewers, which were — not everybody survived. And he thought, well, here is everything, you walk like that. And somebody ask him at night, what it is the —

segments.question: The password.
segments.answer: Password. And he didn’t say. And the — the one who was asking was saying stop and so on, and he didn’t stop because it’s a safe way. And he was killed by that. But, it was right, they never knew what it. So I was in the insurrection up to the very end. And when Polish people managed to get the — Germans called us bandits, but [indecipherable] they really had trouble with us. We were prepared for, I think Interview with Barbara Syska ia October 22, 2014 three days of fighting and three days of ammunition. I have to back then, year earlier, to Holocaust as well.

segments.question: I want to talk about that.
segments.answer: Yes —

segments.question: I want to talk about the ghetto.
segments.answer: — definitely. But here I — I want to go to — to my little hero.

segments.question: Okay, come —
segments.answer: We were sent to Sandbostel, my mother and I, and my father as well. Then, the officers —

segments.question: What is Zen Boston, what is that?
segments.answer: The name in Germany.

segments.question: And what was it?
segments.answer: The camp for — soldiers camp.

segments.question: So you’re talking about prisoner camp.
segments.answer: Prisoner camp.

segments.question: So you’ve jumped between — you know, you had three days of ammunition left?
segments.answer: Well —

segments.question: And then what happened?
segments.answer: The insurrection was 63 days. Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: And at the end of that, Germans wanted to get rid of us, so they said, we are not bandits, we’re soldiers. And from that on, Germans treated us properly, definitely properly, because we were in Sandbostel, somewheres and somewhere else. And my father, from that camp went to Murnau, where is only for officers —

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: — also. And I don’t remember, but I think it was before the Christmas that we were sent to Oberlangen. Oberlangen is close to border of Holland, with empty space all around us. And they sent one after another, they sent women from other prisoners of war, which was definitely very safer for us. My father said that in Sandbostel they were — Polish men were prepared that if we will be freed, they will try to go at any place to our camp, our —

segments.question: Area.
segments.answer: — area, because there are men who are four or five years without women. So Germans took all the women. Before that they ask who wants to work in th — in the country, or something. I think 1t was volunteer everywhere, that m-maybe there was pressure on women, but definitely not pressure on the — physical pressure. No, not physical pressure, psychological pressure. Because a lot of women from the prisoner of camp went to work somewhere. But we went, just sent to that one camp. Interview with Barbara Syska " October 22, 2014

segments.question: I want to interrupt you just for a second, just so that we have the chronology right. The uprising starts on August 1“, 1944, correct?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: It lasts for 63 days, which means that by early October it has been quashed, at which point you’re taken prisoner —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — and your mother is taken prisoner, and your father is taken prisoner.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Were you together at the time, all three of you, or were you separated?
segments.answer: For a day or two we were together. We were marched, I think about 20 kilometers to Ozarow, and then in a very big camp, and then men was separated from women.

segments.question: And then you were —
segments.answer: But we were taken as ordinary soldiers, already.

segments.question: And so then you were put on cattle cars, is that right, on trains to go to Sandbostel’?
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: That’s not comfortable, but is nothing. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Barbara Syska ” October 22, 2014

segments.question: So, when you get to Sandbostel, you are there for how long?
segments.answer: Most likely before Christmas, but I’m not sure whether it before or after Christmas. Then we were taken to Oberlangen, which was an empty space —

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: — with only us.

segments.question: Only women.
segments.answer: Only women, from a different camp. I was in the second barrack.

segments.question: And your — and this was still done by the Germans together, and this was done — did you know why they did this? What was the reasoning?
segments.answer: Why they took all the women together?

segments.question: And — yeah, and put them together?
segments.answer: I’m thinking because they thought that it was safer. They was done properly.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: And we were even received three — three times I think, a parcel from Red Cross. On-Only three, usually it would be more, food or something. Once they sent hygienic things for women, and I learned then everybo — well, we had the little hospital there, for us, and so it was useful. But, more than half of women did not have the usual period, because of the —

segments.question: Stress. Interview with Barbara Syska ” October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Not only stress, hunger.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: We were given food, but Germans didn’t have much of that. We had to work in the kitchen for ourselves, so that’s all again — according to a Geneva Convention.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I cannot say that — somebody once said that it was a special camp or something. It was the proper camp, they treated us properly. We had to go out to bring the potatoes, but I had unusual smell, and they ask me very often, what is in this soup? And I would say that the soup is with salt, or without. Sometimes they didn’t have salt. I cannot say more salty or less, but salt, or without salt, I could smell it at that time. So they always ask me, I never made the mistake. So you see —

segments.question: That’s amazing.
segments.answer: — it was so little —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — that — that — well, we were doing everything. We could do during the day whatever we wanted to. The restroom were outside, of course, not inside. And in one empty hut there was water broken, and even the winter there, it was flowing there, so we would go there, or something like that.

segments.question: So the ice was broken, so there was some water. Interview with Barbara Syska “ October 22, 2014
segments.answer: No, it was broken, ne-never repaired.

segments.question: Oh, you mean the fau —
segments.answer: But it was an empty one. So we were — walked around, there were ma-maybe 10 huts, and only four or five were occupied. Altogether we were close to 2,000, I believe. So —

segments.question: So how large was a hut? How many people fit into one hut?
segments.answer: About 200. And it was three — well, three level of —

segments.question: Well, they were huts, rather than buildings?
segments.answer: Of course, because — and we could wash at the end of the — but to the restroom, we would have to go outside.

segments.question: I see. I see.
segments.answer: But three levels, and of course there were wood, and shins — wood planks, and in the middle of it, there was a stove. And of course, from time to time we took one plank. And so sometimes it was difficult to sleep, no, not to fall down, because on that we had shen-nikeetsa(ph), big bag with straw inside.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Okay.
segments.answer: So — but — and how did I got the — it was close to Dutch border, I had wooden shoes, and for instance, one of my things was how to walk at night. How did I walk to that restroom there on night, so nobody would hear it? Try to walk in the wooden Interview with Barbara Syska ° October 22, 2014 shoes. So that was something what to occupy me, when we didn’t had any pers — anything, we learn history. I started to learn — I-I started to learn English before that, but we had one book. It was [indecipherable] something like that, it — a some book on lowest level, about some murder or something like that.

segments.question: Like a detective novel or something?
segments.answer: M-Most likely detective novel. But the three girls who we-were learning from somebody who knew that, were on much better progress, so I was learning what is here, there, at, and things like that.

segments.question: So they were learning English from the detective novel?
segments.answer: Yes, because we had that detective novel. And it’s still — in Sandbostel we used to walk up and down the corridor there. There we were 1n such a crowd that when we were sleeping on the floor, if we want to turn around, everybody would have to turn around. But there was a corridor on which we could not walk during the night, but during the day. And I and two other girls who were learning English — English was not popular in before the war, only French and German. Russian, we had to learn later, but wasn’t popular. But anyway, so we were talking the whole Polish sentence with one word English which we knew, not to forget. But then in Oberlangen it was already something like that. And of course if we were bored, Interview with Barbara Syska "° October 22, 2014 and if somebody knew something about the subject, there was a conference about that and everybody would cool — come and so it was ordinary —

segments.question: Prisoner of war —
segments.answer: Prisoner of war camp.

segments.question: — camp.
segments.answer: And definitely Germans treated — well, sometimes we, if they couldn’t count correct — nobody run away from the camp, I don’t think so. But if they couldn’t count everybody, because everybody would have to come —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — but somebody sick maybe, we could stand for two or three hours. But that’s the usual in camp. Opposite us, opposite this four or five huts, were the others, and there was that little hospital, which we had for — and also, during that morning and evening —

segments.question: Appel?
segments.answer: — count of us, there were boys. There were soldiers. They were — the oldest one, most likely 12 or 13, and he would say, on top, march, look that, and so on, because they have to be counted. They were soldiers. In my hut, there were two sisters —

segments.question: Also, prisoners of war.
segments.answer: Yes, prisoners of war. Interview with Barbara Syska "t October 22, 2014

segments.question: Prisoner of war, too, okay.
segments.answer: They were, definitely.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: And in my camp, I learned later that bo-both went to Israel. We knew they were Jewish, we can hear a Jewish accent. It’s a some sort of accent, I don’t know whether I would be able to recognize right now. Jewish people had that accent, and the best educated had the best Polish, no accent at all. You hear the much better pronunciation that others. But the just ordinary people had some sort of accent which we could recognize. They definitely had, and the older one looked like Jewish girl. So — with the f-face. Nobody ever mentioned that they were Jewish, of course, because we never knew whether they — even as prisoner of war, whether they would not be taken out. And I was talking to that little one. I think that she was about 10. Apparently, she joined the insurrection, and was a messenger, as I was. And she said her biggest trouble was that when she was sent with messages to people [indecipherable] somewhere in there, and she should not ask people where to go if she mistake it. And she could not read, so she was putting the messages in between her fingers to remember to whom she has to go and show, if she ge-get more.

segments.question: She didn’t know how to read? Interview with Barbara Syska a October 22, 2014
segments.answer: No. Apparently she was in ghetto. There was no schools. Because she must have been —

segments.question: Very little.
segments.answer: — at least nine, but I think she was about 10. And so that’s was a soldier, that’s my little hero — hero.

segments.question: Aye aye, aye aye. So she would in — because she didn’t know how to read, she would put —
segments.answer: She was putting in t — in between her fingers to remember, because she could not ask somebody on the street. She would never know who is that person. So, what she did before, for that year, I don’t know. Maybe she was singing in the streetcars, or so on. There were some songs against Germans, which the — the streetcars were so crowded, and nobody would s — would [indecipherable] anything. What they did before, I did not ask. And apparently — I don’t think that she would be alone with her sister. I don’t know whether it was her sister, they used the same name, last name. But they were so different. One was — my little hero was blonde, and the other one was dark. Everybody liked the little one, we didn’t like very much the other one. They completely different. Most likely they just lived together, maybe they were sisters, I don’t know. But definitely — I don’t remember where I heard, there was a list of people who — women who were in the camp. But then with the Interview with Barbara Syska ” October 22, 2014 age, but I couldn’t find someones who would be — I didn’t know exactly what their age. But le —

segments.question: Were there more Jewish young women who were in the ca — in this prisoner of war camp?
segments.answer: I don’t know definitely. I’m sure that there were more, but this two were in the hut where I was, and I — somehow I talked with that — that little one.

segments.question: And do you remember her name?
segments.answer: No, I don’t.

segments.question: Mm-hm. And the — and back in Warsaw, during the insurrection and even before in the resistance activities, did — did you see any people who were Jewish, who were part of these activities?
segments.answer: No, I was not close to it.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: People in France, for instance, people would be punished, but not us in Poland. In Poland you must have heard about many people who kept Jewish people hiding. And if they would find, the whole family, including small children, would be killed. I was not close to that. Now, I lived in Warsaw, very close to ge — ghetto.

segments.question: Tell me, what did you see there?
segments.answer: Excuse me? Interview with Barbara Syska ” October 22, 2014

segments.question: When you lived close to the ghetto, what did you remember seeing?
segments.answer: That I have to tell you, the ghetto was fighting. First of all, there was a very big wall with the barb wire —

segments.question: Barbed wire, yeah.
segments.answer: — on top of that. I think eight feet, or something like that. On the other side I was walking very often Zelazna.

segments.question: Zelazna, mm-hm.
segments.answer: And so that was — and I think, but right now I don’t remember, but I think that the gate, very often before the insurrection in — 1n the ghetto, the little children sometimes were walking here and there, maybe begging or something, and I think that Germans allowed that.

segments.question: To walk outside the gate, into the —
segments.answer: A little bit.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: A few steps. But I don’t really know whether I remember it right. I think that it was that it was possible.

segments.question: Were you ever inside the ghetto?
segments.answer: No, why?

segments.question: Well, sometimes when you — 101 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: I wouldn’t get out.

segments.question: Yeah. In the early days I have had some other people say there were streetcars that would go through, and so they could take the streetcar in. But that was in the early days of the ghetto.
segments.answer: There was small ghetto and big ghetto.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: I don’t remember next to Zelazna where I was walking, whether that was big or little one, right. And in between there was a street, so you could see it, and people could go from one ghetto to another over that. And that was — now, one of them, the one which was farther away from me, started to fight a few days earlier, I don’t remember. And then I was walking — we were shocked [indecipherable] we knew that they cannot survive, nothing will — there was a Polish underground and Jewish underground, there were some connection, but we didn’t have a lot of ammunition or anything, even for — for our-ourselves, so we didn’t have later. So we couldn’t help, we just had to look helplessly. And we were sorry, looking at — at people who were dying there. But on the very beginning, on that — that other ghetto, other part was fighting and this one not. When I was going through Zelazna street, and over that big wall, I could see a woman — it was April, it was warm enough, she was looking through the window down there. They were not fighting. And she was 102 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 maybe even smiling. She was definitely not — not horrified, not frightened. She was talking to somebody with — it couldn’t — you couldn’t say joy, I — I don’t have the word for that. But I was horrified. How could she be so calm, when she 1s going to die pretty soon? Where her people are dying? It took me a few years to understand that she was proud. She knew what’s waiting for her, and I s — I still can see her how it was, and she took it nicely. She was glad that — that they fighting and not — not allowing to be martyred by — by themselves. It — it give me a — an impression, because we were horrified.

segments.question: Well, that stayed with you.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: That image has stayed with you.
segments.answer: A few weeks or months later, my father — I used to go by streetcar next to all get — the ghetto was always closed to us, afterwards as well. There was streetcar, and he said, don’t go by streetcar today, not this one, because Germans put — hung some people and so high, so you could see it from streetcar, and there were dead people there. So Germans weren’t nice to us. And we learn only that during the insurrection, that there was a prison there, and some people were —

segments.question: Were hung? Were executed?
segments.answer: Re-Rescued then. 103 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014

segments.question: Ah, I see.
segments.answer: And we didn’t know that there was a prison there.

segments.question: Which prison was it? There’s a Pawiak prison, I remember.
segments.answer: No, no, Pawiak, he was somewhere else. It was after — after ghetto da — it was — after the Holocaust —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: — there was a prison there.

segments.question: Within the — within the area of what the ghetto had been?
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: I see. Had you — you know, did people outside the ghetto know of the transports? That is that —
segments.answer: On the very beginning, we didn’t. I knew quite a lot because of my father pretty high position in — in the army. So, for instance, when Russians were coming and are close to Wilno, people were saying we’re Armia Kryova. At first they were treated nicely, but then they were prison there, something. So, before the insurrection, we knew already what was really expecting us, that unless we’ll be strong enough to get Warsaw before the Russians would come in, but they stop, and they didn’t want the allies to — to come in London, whatever, once more they —

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Barbara Syska m October 22, 2014
segments.answer: — they did whatever they —

segments.question: Excuse me for a second, we’ve got people talking out here. [break] We’re going — we’re going to repeat some of the things we were talking about now, because there was some background noise. I was asking you, did you know of — of transports of Jews outside of the ghetto, while you were in Warsaw proper. What was happening to them?
segments.answer: Maybe later we knew. On the very beginning, nobody knows. When ghetto was starting, some couple which were Christian and Russian — and Jewish, they could choose the — at least the wife could stay outside. They usually would choose to go to ghetto together —

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: — because nobody expected that. They expected that people will be separated, but not that. Later they knew and most likely we know. But for quite a time Jewish people didn’t know that when there 1s a transport, the transport is to be killed.

segments.question: So did you know the na — did the — did the terms Auschwitz mean something in 1942 and 1943? Did the term Treblinka mean something?
segments.answer: I don’t know when it’s come. Before the insurrection, before the ghetto up- uprising, we already knew, but —

segments.question: Okay. 105 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: — how long before that, I don’t know.

segments.question: Okay. Okay.
segments.answer: Because we — we knew that German want to kill all the Jewish people.

segments.question: So you did know that. You did know that there was — there was —
segments.answer: But not on the very beginning.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: On the very beginning we didn’t.

segments.question: Did you ever, or did your father ever see any Jews being taken from the ghetto to the train station for such a transport?
segments.answer: No, no, no, no.

segments.question: No, no.
segments.answer: And I never — well, walking around in there, there was that gate. I never seen it, no.

segments.question: Okay, okay.
segments.answer: So, most likely they were already driven by some — something. I don’t know. No.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So during the war I was not involved with any Jewish peop — person trying to get away, or anything like that. I think that I knew the name of a person who was most 106 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 active in ghetto. If you say the name I will tell you that, yes. But — so we know that there is a underground there, but we knew that everybody is helpless. The — our insurrection was prepared for three days only, because we didn’t have the ammunition for everything.

segments.question: Oh, so when you were telling me about three days, it — and it ended up being 63 days —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: That’s what you were explaining. Got it.
segments.answer: Yes. Some was taken from Germans, some was — but very little from the — being thrown by allies, but not Russians. The Russians, on the very end, helped and they s — threw some bread, I had some bread.

segments.question: Oh really? Some bread?
segments.answer: Yes. Completely dry.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: We were hungry, but it was the ammunition which we needed. And they did not let the allies planes land on their side. And because of that there was a lot of people lost because of that.

segments.question: So, were — were —
segments.answer: Russians stopped, because they wanted us to be killed. 107 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014

segments.question: Y-You mean the Russian forces were already at Warsaw and they —
segments.answer: Close to Warsaw —

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: — yes, and they stopped.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: The —

segments.question: And had the — and were the insurrections, the people from the uprising, were they expecting the Russians to come over the — and help out?
segments.answer: Definitely, because they were our allies. We were not in good — in terms with — with them, because of Katyn, and that time only Katyn, not — not the other camps. So it was broken without us, but I think [indecipherable] went to see Stalin just before that, and Stalin didn’t say anything. And no di — they were definitely wanted us to — to be killed off.

segments.question: So tell me a little bit — I'd like to get a sense of how — by the time the news about Katyn was revealed, when the Germans found the site of the massacre of the 4,000 Polish soldiers — Polish military men, were you already in Warsaw?
segments.answer: I was in Warsaw, I don’t remember when it was.

segments.question: Do you remember learning about Katyn in — while you were in Warsaw” 108 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Straightaway, because we knew. The Germans allowed the Polish Red Cross, because they wanted everybody to know what Russians did.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So, there was all the news we knew, and since people were killed in — with their all uniform, there were some papers and things like that, so —

segments.question: So they had identification with them.
segments.answer: Identification. We had not di — doubts that it was the Russians who did it.

segments.question: And were you working at the Red Cross when this news came in, or was this before that time?
segments.answer: I think it was later, could have been later. I don’t remember when it was.

segments.question: Okay. And you mentioned to me earlier when we were not taping, that your father recognized some names. Can you tell me about that?
segments.answer: First of all, the — he was the first one to sign that he wants to come back to his family. And —

segments.question: That’s when he’s still in Lithuania.
segments.answer: In Lithuania.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And then the first transport went out, and he was not on that, so he went back to, most likely the camp — Polish people in the camp, who signed him, and he said, 109 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 why not I should be? And then in the third one, I’m sure that he knew the names, because there was a ter — transport from there. I think that Katyn was not only from his camp, but from the others as well.

segments.question: Course.
segments.answer: I don’t know. I don’t know what the name of his camp was, but definitely he was in the second transport, not the first one.

segments.question: Okay, and so when — when you learned about Katyn —
segments.answer: We knew what it was.

segments.question: Yes —
segments.answer: Only then we learned, because we — before that we didn’t know.

segments.question: Did he recognize some of the names of the people?
segments.answer: Yes, he did.

segments.question: I see. So when he — when the identification list was made, he recognized that some of these people had been in this camp with him?
segments.answer: Yes, because he would not know that the — there was a thir — third transport. They could be from everywhere, but he recognized it — he knew that third one went there as well.

segments.question: I see, I see. So there was no — no doubt in your minds that this was not just German propaganda, this was actually true. 110 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: We knew, we knew, because Germans wanted everybody to know, and because of that they allowed the Red Cross, Polish Red Cross to go there.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And recognize. And there were letters and [indecipherable]. Yes, we knew.

segments.question: So let’s go back to Oberlangen, where you are, you know, you’re — you’re there with about 2,000 other women, prisoners of war, and it’s now like the winter of 1945, the war is coming to an end. Did people in the camp n — have that feeling that it’s not going to be a lot — long now before it’s all over?
segments.answer: Yes, we believe that. And it was funny incidents, there were people in Polish army under British command, and they stopped not close to our camp, and Germans ask, why do you stop here for the night? Why your women are there? Because Germans knew. And so they went. I think we were rescued about five or six o’clock in the afternoon, because they did not know that there was camps.

segments.question: So you were liberated by Polish forces?
segments.answer: Polish forces, yes.

segments.question: Oh, that must have been something.
segments.answer: And that was before the end of the war, about a month, I think about a month. It was April.

segments.question: It was April? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 111 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Okay. So that’s the first time you’re free.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Aside from the time you were in free Poland in that little courtyard.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: This is when you were — what happened to you? What did — what —
segments.answer: Well, after we learn in July that my s — most likely it was beginning of August that we learned that he died, on 27 of July, we decided to go and join our Anders’ Army in Italy. And the detail —

segments.question: Excuse me, I’m sorry. Your mother was with you in Oberlangen?
segments.answer: Yes, and my —

segments.question: And where was your father?
segments.answer: — father came.

segments.question: To Oberlangen?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay, mm-hm.
segments.answer: Just to tell the news.

segments.question: Okay. 112 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: And we went there, and it was the last month when somebody could still join the army. The Anders’ Army was mainly from Siberia, but also quite a lot of people came who were taken to German army, and they would go through the — to Polish — Polish people who were under the occupied person, and they were forcibly joined the German army. So a lot of people came like that, to them. But, since the war was over, they was not taking any new people. But — and at that time we could not go to England. My brother was trying and didn’t before he — he died. And so we’re — we were in Italy. I was in Porto San Giorgio, and that was [indecipherable] Italy. And there was a school for girls who didn’t finish. So there were some from the Polish insurrection, some were through ho — went through Siberia. One of my friend was a tall, well-built woman — girl, at that time. She was in Siberia, she was working in the forest cutting the trees. So that’s not exactly a woman job.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: But otherwise we — we didn’t talk a lot. One was — most of them were driving trucks to supply there. And one of them said that when it was very hot, th-they would put wet sheets on them to — to cool themselves. But otherwise they didn’t say how —

segments.question: What their Siberian experiences were, huh?
segments.answer: No, no. 113 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Nothing like that.

segments.question: But it brought you all so much together, all these people who had such different — different destinies, different hardships, different —
segments.answer: And we didn’t talk about our experiences at all. It was the school and what — how to do it. And under the — under our school, there were food magazines. And so we had lot of rats. And in Italy you have, in Polish it’s [indecipherable] it’s a sort of — something like a — a — over your bed when you sleep, so —

segments.question: A mosquito net.
segments.answer: Mo-Mosquito net. And she put her leg out, and the rat bit her once. My other experience from there was I couldn’t sleep, I went there, and down there, there was — we have military in — people who were taking care of the food under that, and th — about us, and somebody who was passing by, another soldier, came and say, oh well, you have a good — so many women around you. And he th — the one who was there said no, there are good people, good women there.

segments.question: So, in other words, there were people who were looking at you in a different way. 114 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Well, some other people thought that well, when there are women and whatever happened. But no — no, it was — it was not. And the man who — who was there said so. So I heard it. But —

segments.question: We — were these soldiers?
segments.answer: Yes, Polish soldiers.

segments.question: Both pole — yeah.
segments.answer: Polish soldiers.

segments.question: I-I have a question about — about General Anders’ Army. Why would people be joining the army, his army, after the war 1s over? What would have been the reason for that?
segments.answer: We didn’t want to go to Soviet Poland. Poland was not free.

segments.question: So in other words, it would have been now to fight the Soviets?
segments.answer: Well, there were some — I think my daughter-in-law father was in Poland still, after the war, after the insurrection, and he was fighting there. How he got out, I don’t know, because we didn’t talk about those things. But he was one who was still fighting Germans and Russians and he — he was a — we did not fight Russians, because they were allies, so he was still fighting Germans. And there were some people left and in Poland a lot was arrested and killed and so on.

segments.question: By? Interview with Barbara Syska _ October 22, 2014
segments.answer: It’s not — not — for us, the war did not stop there, even for somebody — we could choose to go out of Warsaw as a prisoner or war, or as a civilian. And many people decided to go as civilian. If they were found later by Russians that they were in the underground army, they would be arrested, killed.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So-

segments.question: So even though they were allies, having fought in an underground army, they were threats.
segments.answer: No, no.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: They were not.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: This — right now when I am looking at the Ukraine it’s exactly what’s happen in °39 in Poland, [indecipherable] their people.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Whatever. They don’t mind. So —

segments.question: What happened to you after Italy? What — what happened after that? 116 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: After a year I wanted so much to go to England when my brother was alive — we had to go to England and to be resettled. So I was in the camp there, and another year of school, and so I have my matriculation in Polish system. And —

segments.question: So in other words, you, while your brother was alive, he wasn’t able to get you to England —
segments.answer: But then I had to —

segments.question: — but after he died, you could go.
segments.answer: [had to go. After a year, all the Polish soldiers were there, and tried to be resettled there.

segments.question: I see. Was there any effort to resettle you into Poland?
segments.answer: Whoever want to go, could go. And out of — we were in [indecipherable] this is — there were about 30 girls in [indecipherable]. Two of them went. And if you consider that they were mostly young women, because it was the — we were in school, so it was from say 16 to 20, 22, only two decided to go to Poland.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And that was why there are so many people stayed outside. We didn’t recognize the Poland as it was.

segments.question: Yeah. Interview with Barbara Syska m7 October 22, 2014
segments.answer: And I ne — I thought I send my children when they were grown up, to Poland. My oldest one, I told him, if somebody will ask you something, answer in English, not in Polish, so they will treat you as a foreigner. Because that was at the time when it — it could be dangerous, I didn’t know. He was 16 at that time. But I never expected that I will be able to go to Poland. So, we never expected that, and we — we didn’t expect that at our lifetime, Poland will be free.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: But right now 1s still after Ukraine, what would be next is Lithuania, and Poland, they — they were mentioning that at — at first. But both Lithuania and Poland are in Europe right now —

segments.question: In the European Union.
segments.answer: — and Ukraine is not. So, hopefully they won’t be able to.

segments.question: I want to ask about then your later, your parents, did they go to England with you?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, because they were in the army.

segments.question: Okay. And —
segments.answer: My mother was still teaching. Na — no, she was helping, she wasn’t teaching in school. We had proper teachers, with good education, better than my mother. And my father, he was going to be sort of expert. I don’t know what he was doing before Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 118 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 the war, but when the National Health Service was starting in England, he was supposed to help as an advisor, even without the English language. And then he got tuberculosis and a heart attack. He died on seven heart attack at that time.

segments.question: Oh, my.
segments.answer: He died when he was 64.

segments.question: And this was in what year?
segments.answer: That was in London.

segments.question: And this was in the 50s? In the 1950s or 1960s?
segments.answer: That — it was — no, no, at ‘60 my husband and I came to United States, and I hoped to show the house and everything to my parents, and my father died two years later.

segments.question: So in the early 60s.
segments.answer: They were still in England.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: In England they — they were given the social health, because my — both — well, if my father could not be the expert —

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: — in his [indecipherable] my mother was teaching in Polish schools. The — we have Saturday Polish schools everywhere, always. So she was helping with that. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 119 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 But she could not work without the language. And when you’re older it 1s very difficult to learn.

segments.question: So you — you spent a good decade or more in pole — in England, in the [indecipherable]
segments.answer: Thirteen years.

segments.question: Okay. So —
segments.answer: And then my husband — there was Polish university — college. He was a year ahead of me, and after a time they said we were under the University of London. So we had to pass the exams once a year, and that was a college. And my husband still can — could go in Polish only. I had — I was a year later, in English, and I was not good in English. I failed five times, so I didn’t finish it there. But I wanted to finish it, so when I came to this country, there — in England there is no — nothing. How — you don’t call grades 1s — for each one you have one or two what — I lost the word, I’m telling you

segments.question: It’s okay. So for —
segments.answer: But anyway, I could not pass whatever I already learn in engli— in England, only I had to pass it by exam.

segments.question: Okay. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 120 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: So my husband was teaching at the University of Maryland, and I was studying there. And I finish my study, I have my bachelor at 42.

segments.question: Congratulations. Congratulations.
segments.answer: It wasn’t easy. I just wanted to finish.

segments.question: And he — he — was it — and so if I understand it properly, it was that he was able to pass his exams in England in the Polish language —
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: — which made it easier. And by the — and you, coming a year later, had to take those exams in English, even though you knew the subject matter. Then, because it was in English, it was hard for you to do.
segments.answer: Well, I had to pass five exams. One was most likely mathematics; physics and something like that. Lab. And I was passing four, and the fifth was English, which I could not pass. I think five times I failed.

segments.question: I see.
segments.answer: So then I was studying by myself with the books, which — at home. But that gave me knowledge, but nothing. And when we came to this country t — first two years I didn’t do anything. And then I join and — at University of Maryland, my husband was teaching there, we wer — lived in Maryland, but they said, you have to pay as much as a foreigner. Not lower as Marylander. Contact reference@ushmm org for further information about this collection 121 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: So I was really angry with that — them. But later I was going to get my bachelor and then fight by-laws with that. And [indecipherable] some Chinese or somebody else did it before me.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: So it was changed. But it was hard on us, because we didn’t have money, and here I had to pay a li — right now 1s very, very little, but it’s — it still was a lot for us.

segments.question: It was — yeah.
segments.answer: We came to this country with four children, two were born in this country.

segments.question: So you have four children? That’s was my next —
segments.answer: Six children right now.

segments.question: You have six children?
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Twenty-three grandchildren, and 17 great-grandchildren.

segments.question: Oh my goodness.
segments.answer: Yes, I am rich.

segments.question: How wonderful. How wonderful. I take it your husband is also po — was also Polish? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection 122 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Yes, we lived in Warsaw a few blocks away, but we met in England. He went through the insurrection, through Italy. In Italy he was studying at Turin University. How he did, I don’t know, because he did — didn’t know span —

segments.question: Italian?
segments.answer: Italian. So maybe that’s where something in English, I — I don’t know.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: But he —

segments.question: And why —
segments.answer: — was studying there for a year.

segments.question: — why did you leave the U.K. to come to the United States? What was the reason?
segments.answer: My husband started to study in England, higher degree. Somebody advised him to — to go to one place, and to do [indecipherable] engineering, and he finish master in engineering. And he hated if somebody will call him engineer. He wanted to study mathematics. And his professor in Polish university told him, you are too old for that. He finish, he got the doctorate in mathematics. And apparently, it was so well thought in this country about the degree he got in England, that he went with somebody he knew from one of the meeting of people with — whatever their interest. He took him and my husband got seven offers of a job. 123 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014

segments.question: Wow.
segments.answer: And he choose, like that, Maryland, and we are in Maryland ever since.

segments.question: Oh my. And you said you have six children?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And we talked about this a little bit earlier, but tell me, have — do your children know your story, your history, your experiences?
segments.answer: I know that my daughter once said something was so — so out of reason. So apparently we didn’t talk enough about it.

segments.question: I see. I see. Do any of the grandchildren express interest or curiosity about these things?
segments.answer: Sometimes I talk, but I think they don’t think it’s very important. I don’t know.

segments.question: Okay. What would you want younger generations to understand about what your generation went through, what your parents’ generation went through?
segments.answer: Somehow I’m dissatisfied with people who right now go out and there’s no — not enough work in Poland, so when they can go anywhere in Europe to — to work, they do. I — they don’t really think of coming back. They don’t think really that they should belong to Poland and not to be outside this. And it seems to me they’re — they’re a completely different generation. I lived in free Poland, which was under 150 years when we were not free. And right now some people are — in Poland are 124 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 mixed up, and they don’t recognize that they were not free under the Soviet occupation. There is a lot of progress in the country, as I — I think I mentioned to you that my brother wanted to go on the bicycle to — from Bialystok to Warsaw. And that half of main road was paved and some half wasn’t. Right now, even in the village where my mother lived there, everything is paved. There is electricity. Right now there are a lot of trees, say cherry trees, which are si — small. So it’s easy to pick. So you have to —

segments.question: They’ve been — they’ve been raised that way, yeah.
segments.answer: — start — raised like not — not only it’s a different kind of cherries, not the big one. So that had to be change, you don’t change it from year to year, you have to do it. And there, in that village where my mother was teaching, there was about 2,000 people, and one — one with higher education only. So education was allowed, but also some people were pushed, and they should not have the — that higher education. But definitely everybody has the — much more opportunity. So, the villages went up, and because of that, some people from there don’t feel that we were not free for so many years. We — us being outside, we knew what was happening. They accepted what it was, and it wasn’t a free Poland. So —

segments.question: And so you’d want people to have a — have a greater understanding of what freedom means. 125 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Yes. And maybe it’s coming. Some people say that schools are not as — as good as it used to be. I know from my mo-mother that after we got independence in [indecipherable] the schools were — they were supposed to be like the schools in Switzerland. That was the example for us. But my mother wa-was going with some inspector, wh-who — who he was I don’t know, about once a year for three days, to different schools in the country, where the teacher would have to pass an exam to be

segments.question: A teacher, yeah.
segments.answer: — a teacher there. So some people were not very well educated, and the schools went — the level of schools went up and apparently they say that right now is going down. I don’t know why.

segments.question: It happ — you know, the — it still 1s countries in development, after — after such changes, it takes a while for — for systems to work, and to improve.
segments.answer: Yes. There — right now there are changes there — in Poland, children start at seven, they start at six or something. And they — I don’t understand what, but —

segments.question: I wanted to ask — yeah.
segments.answer: — something is not — not very good.

segments.question: I wanted to ask this question in a different way. What would you want young people, and younger generations from other countries: from the United States, from 126 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 Canada, from the U.K., from Germany, and even from Russia, and from countries outside of the European experience, what would you want the children of these countries to understand what you and your family, and the people in Bialystok, and the people in Warsaw went through? What do you think you’d like them to be able to get about that?
segments.answer: I don’t think they would learn by themselves if the — if something will happen. But what I am not — people — other people are always dissatisfied, I don’t like what’s right now common in the world that the countries are not religious countries. Poland was definitely Catholic country, but there was tolerance to everybody. And as I said, th-the kids who were going out of religious classes, they enjoyed that. And they could stay and learn.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Not pray, but learn.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And it seems to me that only religion, when you believe — we believe in the same God, only different, and of course, I — I believe it is better than [indecipherable]. But is the same God. And people need to — to believe in God, whatever it is. If they don’t know, they even form belief that in several gods, or whatever, I don’t know what Buddhists believe, and so on. But there is a tolerance, and it was tolerance in 127 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014 Poland. But here, right now, I — I — is my — my own saying, that et — atheists are not tolerant. They cannot tolerate cross somewhere on the street and somewhere. Maybe they feel guilty that they don’t believe in God, but I don’t see tolerance in this country, and everywhere. And Poland right now is — 1s separate of state and — and — and I think it’s going the same direction, lack of tolerance. And I’m very dissatisfied with that, so I don’t know whether people can change it again, back to religious tolerance. Well, we have Muslims in Poland, some gathering, they — they have the — right now they moved from east to west and so on, so it’s more difficult, but those people were — Poland was always fighting Turks and — and Tartars, they were Muslims. So those people were taken prisoners, or were — they were always — they started as our enemies, fighting us. And right now we consider them just any other people. We don’t have problem with — with Muslims right now in Poland.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But we are tolerant to any religious, and it seems to me that if — well, with Muslims it’s difficult because not all of them are — are fighting.

segments.question: That’s right.
segments.answer: But it seems to me I would like young people to believe that religion is the base of the social work.

segments.question: Okay. 128 Interview with Barbara Syska October 22, 2014
segments.answer: Social —

segments.question: Cohesion, in some ways.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Of society.
segments.answer: But that’s my thing. I-I don’t know what else I would like for the children, I don’t — I do want them to — to believe in God.

segments.question: Okay. Well, thank you, thank you, Mrs. Syska, for sharing your life, your thoughts, your experiences with us today. I’m very grateful for it. And this then, concludes the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum interview with Barbara Syska on augu — on, excuse me, October 22", 2014. Thank you very much.
segments.answer: Thank you. End of File Two Conclusion of Interview
